Key Arguments: The legislation fails to provide procedural fairness and denies natural justice.
It limits freedom of speech and online discussion in a democratic society.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are vague and subjective.
The definition of harm is too broad and could be misused.
The legislation could lead to excessive litigation and restrict diverse opinions.
There is no clear provision for review or appeal.
Onerous duties are placed on content platform providers, leading to excessive content restriction.
Notable Quotes: The legislation ultimately provides the government to quell any opposing views and to ensure that freedom of speech and online discussion are unfairly limited in a democratic society.
It is impossible to be clear whether a person intends to deceive or whether, in their opinion they are trying to inform.
This legislation goes far beyond the legal structure of Duty of Care.

The vagueness of these terms is reminiscent of legislation in some foreign countries that enables governments to detain its citizens for making statements or taking actions deemed 'not in the National interest'.
The legislation may result in platforms severely limiting their users to make any statements because any statements might contravene the legislation.
